Award.AwardTitle: Developing Methods for High-resolution Measurements of Enveloped Virus Budding in Live Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit. Understanding the mechanics of virus budding is the focus of this research. This project employs state-of-the-art light microscopy to visualize the interactions of viral and cellular proteins that work together to facilitate the escape of mature viruses from mammalian cells. Many viruses, including the vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV), which is the subject of this research, and the better-known HIV, employ an escape strategy to exit cells once they have invaded and replicated themselves. This escape strategy requires the action of both viral and cellular proteins. Regular cellular proteins are redirected from their normal cellular locations and activities to the sites of virus budding. The exit process involves a large number of recruited cellular proteins and thus is complex, and while many of the key proteins have been identified, the manner and timing of their recruitment to the cell membrane and the interactions between them are only vaguely understood. Through recombinant virus technology and high-resolution live cell imaging, this project will investigate the timing and mechanisms of protein recruitment to the membrane thereby identifying rate-limiting steps and crucial interactions between proteins. The insights gained through this research promise to increase our basic understanding of the mechanisms involved in viral infection of cells.

Broader impacts. This project draws heavily from both biology and physics, two disciplines that have historically been separate but which blend together powerfully in the emerging study of cellular biophysics. Students will receive the important benefit of training in both biology and physics, allowing them to approach biological problems using rigorous quantitative analytical skills. This project embodies a strong commitment to the education of women and underrepresented groups. The project also involves outreach activities for both undergraduate and secondary school students, including in particular recruitment of high school and junior high school students from disadvantaged areas of Salt Lake City. This project emphasizes multi-disciplinary training and student opportunities, and possesses the potential to achieve important new insights into basic mechanics of virus replication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has supported research into two classes of viruses very harmful to humans, specifically retroviruses (e.g. HIV) and Negative strand RNA viruses (e.g. VSV, Ebola and measles).

HIV Background: After infecting the cell, HIV synthesizes its own proteins and starts to build new viruses through polymerization of its newly synthesized proteins on the inner leaflet of the host cell surface. As the proteins assemble, the surface/membrane of the host buds out until all the proteins and genomic RNA from the virus are packaged inside the bud. At this point, HIV recruits cellular proteins named ESCRTs to cut itself loose from the host cell. ESCRTs main function within the cell are in separating two daughter cells during cell division and recycling of membrane receptors.

Our HIV contributions: We utilized this award to develop a new form of imaging which focuses the light on the surface of the cells. Using this technique we can measure the number of HIV proteins accumulating in the forming viruses on the surface of infected cells. To achieve this in a safe way, we performed our experiments in a minimal system which does not produce infectious viral particles, instead creates virus like particles (VLPs) that are released from infected cells. The resolution of our microscope is high enough to clearly separate individual forming VLPs on the surface of the cell. We utilized this microscopy system to 1- show that there are unexplained pauses during the formation of new VLPs. We hypothesize that these pauses correspond to a deficit in recruitment of a viral or cellular factor needed in the assembly of HIV, identification of this factor is currently underway in our lab as well as in our collaborators. 2- We showed that the ESCRT proteins are recruited transiently at the end of assembly during VLP formation. This recruitment profile was unexpected and opened a question about regulatory mechanisms required for ESCRT recruitment which is currently under investigation in our lab. Two peer reviewed manuscripts were published based on our work on HIV and a graduate student is currently finalizing her thesis to obtain her PhD based on the HIV work supported by this award. A news release of our discovery was published at:

http://nsf.gov/discoveries/disc_summ.jsp?cntn_id=131397&org=NSF

Negative strand RNA viruses

background: Viruses that encode their genome as a negative strand RNA form a large group of deadly human pathogens including Ebola, measles and Rabies. This family also includes a live stuck virus named vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) which is much safer to handle in the lab but shares most of the replication mechanism in the family, our lab used VSV to understand how this family of viruses replicate within their host. These RNA viruses have a common problem, they have to protect the fragile RNA genome from the host cell and therefore the RNA genome is tightly bound with nucleoproteins resembling a tightly packed bead necklace. To read this protected genome, these viruses have to package a special RNA dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) enzyme. While the genome is long (10kb or ~4 microns in physical dimensions), it is known that the RdRPs can only successfully read the genome starting from one end (the 3’ end of the RNA). While they eventually get to read all the genes embedded linearly on the genome, how they start the reading process is a mystery.
